replies.commentText:
I applaud you.  I've had a hard time distinguishing people for criteria other than character, action, and personal hygene (I've been a hiring manager for a hotel, it was surprisingly relevant).  I'm lucky to have the outlook I do as it's afforded me so many enriching connections, resounding conversations, and lasting friendships with people ranging from 12 to 92.  To see people as simply Humans, extend them courtesy and a standard measure of respect, then see who they are by word and action, THAT is to really see them.  Had a felony conviction in your 20's and been out for 30 years, fought to build a mechanic shop through many prejudices/difficulties, and your favorite thing is baking - I want to hear your story and chat about life!
I'd be truly sorry to miss out on that.  Until I see a person is either unapproachable, uninterested, or unable to converse I'm glad of any opportunity to connect... because we're all in this together and it's later than we think.
@Cannon Overture this is such a beautiful share.  Very encouraging to hear!!! So well written. Thank you!!

While treating anyone with condescending tone isn't appropriate, I think the society today is extremely different than, say, 100 years ago. But first of all, this video has a serious flaw: what exactly is " old people?" Quite frankly, no one can deny the huge difference between a 65 years old person and a 95 year s old one, therefore, wouldn't it be inappropriate - and quite condescending - to group them under the same category in the first place? Take my grandma for example. When she was 65, she was really strong and healthy and could take care the house in a way that no one else could in my family. But now, when she is in her 90s, not only it is already difficult for her just to stay awake, but mentally she has lost the sharpness she had at 65 and has become agonizingly stubborn. So really, this video asks and answers a wrong question in the first place. Especially nowadays the average life span has become so ... .."old?" that it is not uncommon for people to live nearly a third of their lives as "old persons" while the society is changing ever so quickly t hat "old experience" becomes obsolete in just a couple decades in many cases. Aging is a gradual process. This video asks an oversimplified question with an oversimplified answer.

replies.commentText: Her point is that precise grade divisions are arbitrary and skew our socialization. Before industrial-style schools were created, students just progressed whenever their teachers thought they were ready, and students dropped out of school or were sent off to higher education whenever they or their teachers decided it was time. (There were a lot more teenagers in universities in the past.) Now we treat it as perfectly normal that virtually every student receives exactly 13 years of pre-university education and takes most of their classes with others born within the same 365-day period.

Whew, there's a lot of irrational " ageism" in many of the comments below. While it's true that some older people develop clinically identifiable mental disabilities, many, or perhaps most of them, do not. Both my father and grandfather made it to their mid-90's, and they were both mentally as sharp as tacks when they finally croaked. I'm 74, myself, and am still in full possession of my faculties. In fact, my awareness and understanding of the world around me, as well as of my inner life, seem to be getting deeper as I age. Generally speaking, when I interract with younger people, I get the impression that THEY are relatively shallow and limited in their mentality. I don't exclude myself from that assessment. When reflecting on my past, I am often amazed at how ignorant, stupid, and "unconscious" I was in my earlier years. So, kids, never underestimate the wisdom and perspective gained wi th age.

I always shake my head when people start their argument with "150 years ago life was better, because..." We do not live 150 years ago. We live now. Society and the pace of life is completely different. Centuries past people sang the same songs sitting in the same taverns that their grandfathers' grandfathers. Now with fashion and ideologies rapidly shifting I do not have much common ground even with my 38 years older father. Why would I want to constantly hang out with people who do not know the same music, movies, books and problems (etc) that I know? Obviously I oversimplified this. replies.commentText: How is dear ok but honey isn't, lmao...
@mfmageRaids Well that's just how I learned long ago.

@mfmageRaids I agree. And "darling"...? I think dear is on the same level as honey and sweetie. Baby is an weird, awkward choice to use for someone who's not your child or significant other. And it seems dated, like from the '70s: "You've come a long way, baby." Same for darling too, actually. Seems very intimate, so I'm not sure why he's okay with dear and darling, but not the others. ? Is it a Southern US thing, "How ya doin' today, darlin'?" I suppose if it's a cultural thing and just said generally to people, it's no big deal. If dear, honey, sweetie are used with a kind tone and intention, I have no problems with those nicknames. Certain people are affectionate in their speech and call lots of people sweetie. It's different when those names are used as a come-on to be more intimate with someone the speaker isn't close to, who may not feel comfortable with those pet names. Or used with a sarcastic, condescending, or passive-aggressive tone and intent. It's usually pretty clear by the message that the speaker/writer is using the names to hit on or to demean the other. But with an elderly person, asking, "Can I get you anything else, sweetie?" seems like something a caregiver, server, nurse, etc would say with concern for the other person. I feel it's all about the tone, intent, and general personality of the speaker.
@mfmageRaids Dear in my view is acceptable. A formal business letter starts with the term so there's that. Honey implies sweetness and so on. Dear does not.
@kd1s LMAO...you do realize Dear at the start of a letter is a verb, not a noun, right?
@Alex Accardi Yes of course. I've always felt a little uncomfortable using it to start a letter though.
